monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The Red Fort was commissioned by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in 1638 when he decided to shift the capital of the Mughal Empire from Agra to Delhi.
It was designed by Ustad Ahmad Lahori, the same architect who designed the Taj Mahal, and took several years to complete, involving thousands of laborers.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: The Red Fort is located in the heart of Old Delhi, India, near the banks of the Yamuna River, which made it a strategic site for defense and trade.
It is situated in close proximity to other historic sites, such as Chandni Chowk and Jama Masjid, adding to the rich cultural tapestry of the area.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Construction of the Red Fort began in 1638 and was completed in 1648, marking a decade-long effort to build this massive structure.
It was completed during the reign of Shah Jahan, symbolizing the height of Mughal architecture and their dominance in India.

monumentInformation.title: How Is It Protected By
details: The Red Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognized for its architectural splendor and historical importance in India's history.
It is maintained and preserved by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which ensures its structural integrity and manages public access.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: The Red Fort was built to serve as the main residence of the Mughal emperors and a symbol of their power and authority over India.
It was also constructed to protect the Mughal capital, showcasing both the military and aesthetic grandeur of Shah Jahanâ€™s reign.
